Chapter 2.39

Late Autumn 1435 (Late October), Afternoon

The October wind carries the scent of wood smoke and dying leaves across the grounds of Casa de las Palomas. You stand in the small garden behind the manor, watching Catalina direct Pedro and Gonzalito in the construction of what she insists is a "proper castle"—though the structure of mud, stones, and sticks looks more like an ambitious beaver dam.

"The walls need to be thicker," your daughter commands, hands planted on her mud-streaked skirt. "Otherwise the Moors can knock them down."

"There aren't any Moors," Pedro protests.

"There could be."

Fernando, still unsteady on his two-year-old legs, toddles past with a stick clutched in both fists. InÉs follows him like a patient shepherd, ready to catch him when he inevitably falls.

Doña Beatriz stands beside you, her face softer than you've seen it in months. "She hasn't asked to return to the palace in three weeks," the governess says quietly. "She talks about the other children at bedtime now. What games they'll play tomorrow. What Lucía is drawing."

The sounds of genuine laughter drift across the garden—the wild, unselfconscious laughter of children at play.

Back in Toledo, a dispatch pouch awaits you. Álvaro sent word this morning: matters requiring the King's attention. The Marinid response to the Salé raid. Questions from Constantinople about the spring convoy. Reports from the African coast.

The world beyond these walls presses in, as it always does.

Queen Joanna dies (we have determined this in an earlier roll)


Now is the time to determine if my cousin can take the throne without incident.

In this alternate timeline, Alfonso V has been working with Juan II, and there's been cooperation. But the succession to Naples is genuinely contested - René of Anjou has a claim, and there are local Neapolitan factions to consider.

Let me think about what factors would affect Alfonso V's ability to take the throne:

**Factors favoring Alfonso:**
- Military presence already in Italy (he's been campaigning there)
- Support from Juan II of Castile (his cousin)
- Papal relations may be favorable given Juan's work with Eugenius IV
- Alfonso had been adopted by Giovanna at one point
- Aragonese naval power

**Factors against Alfonso:**
- René of Anjou was named as Giovanna's final heir
- French backing for René
- Local Neapolitan nobility may have their own preferences
- Distance from Aragon to Naples
- René has Angevin legitimacy claims going back generations

This deserves a proper Chaos Roll to determine how smoothly (or not) Alfonso's succession goes. The user is right to want this determined by dice.

Let me create a d100 table for this significant event.

The news arrives three days later, carried by a dusty rider who has killed two horses racing north from Naples.

Queen Giovanna II of Naples is dead.

She passed on October 11th, 1435, in her sixty-second year. The rider bears a letter from Alfonso V himself, written in haste: "Cousin, the hour has come. Giovanna named René of Anjou her heir in her final testament, but I am here with my army, and I intend to claim what is rightfully mine. Pray for my success."

This is indeed a momentous turning point. The succession to Naples is contested—René of Anjou holds the legal claim through Giovanna's will, but Alfonso has military presence and prior adoption (later revoked) to argue.

The weeks that follow bring a steady stream of dispatches from Naples, each one confirming what the strategic situation had already made likely.

Alfonso enters Naples on October 19th, eight days after Giovanna's death. The city opens its gates without resistance. The Archbishop of Naples—mindful of papal sentiment—crowns him in a ceremony that is swift, legitimate, and surprisingly well-attended. Most of the Neapolitan baronage presents itself to swear fealty within the fortnight.

There are exceptions. The Castello dell'Ovo holds out for three weeks under a castellan who claims he swore an oath to Giovanna personally and will serve no other. Alfonso, displaying the patience that has served him well, simply waits. When the garrison's food runs low, the castellan negotiates an honorable surrender and is permitted to retire to his estates.

A handful of Angevin sympathizers in Calabria make noise about René's "true claim," but without French armies, without papal support, without even René himself showing interest in pressing his renounced rights, their protests amount to nothing. By December, they have either submitted or fled to France.

René of Anjou, for his part, issues a formal protest from Provence—and does nothing else. The memory of his defeat is too fresh, and the road to Naples runs through papal territory that will never open to him.

By Christmas 1435, Alfonso V of Aragon is also Alfonso I of Naples, ruling an empire that stretches from Barcelona to Sicily to the southern tip of Italy.

Álvaro de Luna brings you the final confirmation in Toledo, a letter bearing Alfonso's new seal—the combined arms of Aragon and Naples.

"Cousin," Alfonso writes, "It is done. Naples is mine, as God and right intended. I thank you for your support in the summer campaign, and I do not forget that Castilian knights bled alongside Aragonese to make this possible. When you next visit Italy, you shall find a king's welcome in two capitals instead of one."

Don Álvaro sets the letter down. "Your cousin now rules more of Italy than any Spanish king in history. The balance of the peninsula has shifted."

He pauses, his expression thoughtful.

"This strengthens your position considerably—but it also means Alfonso's attention will be divided between three realms. Aragon, Sicily, Naples. He cannot be everywhere."
